DOC.brief_summary: Primary aim of this study is to evaluate the association between postoperative cognitive dysfunction and increased serum levels of S100B protein after robot-assisted laparoscopic radical prostatectomy.
DOC.brief_title: S100B Protein and Postoperative Cognitive Dysfunction
DOC.detailed_description: The neurocognitive assessment protocol will design to evaluate general cognitive function and identify patients with cognitive dysfunction. Neuropsychological tests of all patients will conduct on the one day prior to surgery, the first day after surgery, and the 30 th day after surgery, respectively. According to a consensus statement, cognitive function will assess using a battery of seven neuropsychological tests: Rey Auditory Verbal Learning Test (delayed recall), Trail Making Test (Parts A and B), Digit Span Test (forward and backward), and Grooved Pegboard Test (dominant and non-dominant hands). Postoperative cognitive dysfunction (POCD) was defined as a decline of >20% from preoperative test scores in at least two of seven tests. Serum levels of S100B protein will obtain from venous blood samples collected before surgery, after the anesthesia induction, immediately after surgery and 24 h postoperatively.
DOC.criteria: over 50 years old scheduled for roboticassisted laparoscopic radical prostatectomy the body mass index ranged from 18 kg/m2 to 25 kg/m2 American Society of Anesthesiologists class I, II or III Patients with previous neurological deficit (symptomatic stroke, hemorrhage, transient ischemic attack) other neurologic disorders (epilepsy, trauma, intra or extracranial malignancy) psychiatric diseases (schizophrenia, or depressive disorder) alcoholism or any other drug dependence serious hearing or visual impairment
